posts.post_text: May 19, 2016 at 6:41 PM#3assign macro 1.mymacro.myline /cmd="my command"Sometimes, you can also write every lines you'll need and then enable or disable it :assign macro 1.mymacro.myline /disabled=(yes or no)

posts.author: Buzz313th
posts.post_text: May 21, 2016 at 7:44 PM#4I had a go experimenting with creating macros with macros and this is what I found.You first need to store the macro alone...store macro 1.1.1Then you need to add the lines...store macro 1.1.1 thru 5Then you can edit the lines....assign macro 1.1.1 thru 5 /cmd="test text"I could not figure out the macro to do all in one line, unless you seperate the command syntax with a semicolon.Interestingly enough, as Ryan mentioned there doesn't seem to be a way to edit a macro with a command line..  I tried the syntax "delete macro 1.1.3" and it did nothing, thinking I could delete an existing line and then just add it back to assign a different command line..   But it looks like you would need to delete the macro and start over.   Maybe its possible with LUA?JB
